commit_description:
There are now two types of global bans: IP bans and user bans:

* If logged in and trusted, POST requests will check if the user is user
  banned.
* If logged in and *not* trusted, POST requests will check if the user
  is user banned *and* IP banned.
* If not logged in, only IP bans will be checked on POST. This excludes
  /login, which is somehow magically exempt from the ban listener (which
  is exactly what we want anyway).

Additonally, many smaller fixes have been applied to vaguely ban-related
stuff. For instance, the IP ban form now uses DTOs, and the ban landing
page was moved to its own controller class in order to reduce the number
@IsGranted annotations.

commit_description:
The upgrade to Symfony 3.4 is necessary for the logout_on_user_change
option. Additionally, we've upgraded to SensioFrameworkExtraBundle 5.x.
Changes that result from this are:

* Use of the @IsGranted annotation instead of

in most cases.
* Alter controller methods that take a $subject parameter, since that's
  an internal name that causes @ParamConverer to break. Earlier, $user
  was an internal name, which is why we had parameters named $subject in
  the first place.
* Some instances of @ParamConverter were replaced with the new @entity
  annotation, which is way less verbose.

commit_description:
This changes the following:

- 'open external links in new tab' option is now respected for markdown links.
  The options are fingerprinted and included in the cache key.
- HTMLPurifier/CommonMark services are removed. The MarkdownConverter class
  takes care of instantiating the things it needs.
- a 'cache.markdown' cache pool was created for caching converted markdown.
  This has its own expiry time set, so the CachedMarkdownConverter class is no
  longer responsible for setting the expiry time.
- a separate MarkdownContext class was added for providing MarkdownConverter
  options specific to context
- formatting stuff was moved into a separate twig extension
- the AppExtension and VersionPass classes were changed so the former has
  arguments set by the latter instead of using setters
- unit tests were added for most of the new things

commit_title: upgrade deps and remove UuidAware* workarounds
fix minor privilege escalation related to stickies
optimise SQL queries on front page
commit_description:
- remove need for joins to retrieve submissions from the right forums.
- disable output walkers and fetch-joins, since they appear to not be
  needed.

According to the profiler, this shaves about 20ms off the time it takes
to run database queries.

commit_description:
Setters for IDs are useless since IDs are never assigned
programatically, and the RDBMS seems to override those that are manually
assigned anyway. Setters for collections are useless because they
overwrite the existing collection. Additionally, every getter for a
collection returns a Collection object with add/remove methods for
manipulating collections (which I rarely do to begin with), so there's
really no point in having setters at all. For classes where
adding/removing stuff to collections occur often, we can just have
adder/remover methods for convenience.
